author: John McDuling
title: Why Elon Musk and Tesla are taking the long road
text:
Tesla cut its sales forecast, and is being hurt by strength in the US dollar. Photo: AFP/Stan Honda
Elon Musk's electric car and battery maker, Tesla, reported earnings on Thursday morning, and they weren't very well received on Wall Street.
Shares tanked by nearly 6 per cent in after-hours trading .
Tesla cut its sales forecast, and is being hurt by strength in the US dollar. While its revenue was up 24 per cent from last year, it net loss nearly tripled.
.
But Musk has the perfect excuse.
"Simply put, in a choice between a great product or hitting quarterly numbers, we will take the former," he wrote in a letter to shareholders.
"To build long-term value, our first priority always has been, and still is, to deliver great cars."
For now, at least. While CEOs are often disparaged for short-termism, that critique can't be levelled at Musk.
It takes time to build a truly disruptive, growth business.
Particularly in an industry as capital intensive - and competitive - as cars. How long investors are prepared to go along for the ride remains to be seen.
